page.title: 02BURRINGTON RADAR STATION
page.content: Mr. Crisp told us that it is the most westerly of the eight radar stations which control civil aircraft by overlapping radar cover. Civil aircraft fly at a minimum height of 20,000 ft. on special routes between reporting points. The airways, identified by a colour and a number, are 1,000 ft. apart. Our radar station was built by 1973 and employs 16 people. Radar works by line of sight. There are{two green primary scanners which receive reflections from weather, hills and planes from a pulse of 2 million watts. The{two grey SSR {scanners}receive signals from planes carrying special equipment. These are turned into computer information which is sent to West Drayton.The cabins on the towers house the motors which rotate the scanners 8 times a minute. The scanners have a{160 mile range.}
